description: Settlement activity detected on a site dating to the late 4th or early 5th CE. The site shows evidence of a Middle or Late Iron Age settlement, but this is not continuous with the later activity. An extensive midden pit demarcated by ditches and dating to the late 4th or early 5th CE provided extensive material suggesting religious activity including a curse tablet. The pit was likely formed during a single event, and has been used to suggest the presence of an as of yet undetected shrine.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Land Adjacent to Wayside Farm, Nurseed Road, Devizes (Wiltshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.

Valentin, J. “An Archaeological Field Evaluation of a Proposed Residential Development on Land at Wayside Farm, Nursteed Road, Devizes, Wiltshire.” [object Object], 1999. https://doi.org/10.5284/1029163.
Valentin, J, and S Robinson. “Excavations in 1999 on Land Adjacent to Wayside Farm, Nursteed Road, Devizes” 95, no. Wiltshire Archaeol Natur Hist Mag 95 (2002): 147–213.
